{{Infobox person | name = C. K. G. Billings | image = dillonswin.jpg | image_size = 287px | caption = C.K.G. Billings with his horse Lou Dillon fter winning the Webster Cup in 1903 | birth_name = | birth_date = September 17, 1861 | birth_place =[[Saratoga Springs, New York]], U.S. | death_date = May 6, 1937 | death_place = [[Santa Barbara, California]], U.S. | death_cause = | resting_place = [[Graceland Cemetery]], [[Chicago, Illinois]] | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | known_for = | education = | alma mater= | employer = | occupation = | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = | box_width = }}
'''Cornelius Kingsley Garrison Billings''' (September 17, 1861 in [[Saratoga Springs, New York|Saratoga]], [[New York (state)|New York]] – May 6, 1937 in [[Santa Barbara, California|Santa Barbara]], [[California]]) was a wealthy industrialist tycoon,<ref name=greater /> philanthropist, art collector, and a noted horseman and horse breeder.<ref name=death /><ref name=hervey /> An eccentric man,<ref name=death /> Billings invested much of his time and money promoting the sport of [[harness racing|trotting]], also known as "harness racing" or "matinee racing".<ref name=hervey />
== Life and career == Billings was born in [[Saratoga, New York]] on September 17, 1861, the son of Albert M. Bilings, a resident of Vermont,<ref name=hervey>Hervey, John Lewis (May 12 & 19, 1937) [http://www.mi-harness.net/publct/hh/billings.html "C. K. G. Billings: 1861 - 1937: In Memorium"] ''Harness Horse''</ref> and Augusta S. Billings née Farnsworth. He was raised in [[Chicago, Illinois]] from the age of three, attended schools in Chicago, and then [[Racine College]] in [[Racine, Wisconsin]]. When he finished college at 17 years old in 1879, he joined the [[Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company]] – of which his father was a principal investor and president – beginning as a laborer.<ref name=hervey /><ref name=rush>Rush, Paul (January 11, 2009) [http://paulrush-newyorkstories.blogspot.com/2009/01/horseback-dinner.html "The Horseback Dinner"] ''Paul Rush New York Stories''</ref><ref name=death /> When he became the firm's president in 1887,<ref name=death /> he brought about the mergers from 1895 to 1910 of 12 gas companies into Peoples Gas.<ref>[https://accel.peoplesgasdelivery.com/company/history.aspx "Our History"] [[Peoples Energy]] website</ref> He became chairman of the board of the company in 1901, a position he held until 1911.<ref name=death />
In 1885, Billings married Blanche E. MacLeish, whose father, Andrew MacLeish, was one of the founders of the Chicago [[department store]] [[Carson, Pirie, Scott and Company Building|Carson, Pirie, Scott and Company]].<ref name=hervey /><ref name=death /> They had a son, Albert Merritt Billings, who died in 1926;<ref name=death /> Billings endowed the Billings Memorial Hospital in Chicago as tribute to him.<ref name=hervey /> They also had a daughter, who married Halstead Van der Poel.<ref name=hervey />
During his years in Chicago, Billings was the founder and a charter member of the Chicago Athletic Club, served on the West Park Commission, and on the board of the 1893 [[World's Columbian Exposition]].<ref name=hervey />
In 1901, at the age of 40, Billings, who had inherited a controlling interest in Peoples Gas, but had retired from the day-to-day running of the company,<ref name=rush /> moved to [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], where he and his family lived in a townhouse on [[Fifth Avenue]] at [[53rd Street (Manhattan)|53rd Street]].<ref name=dim />
Billings, who owned 75 racing or trotting horses, would later build an extensive estate in Upper Manhattan, on the site of what is now [[Fort Tryon Park]], but first built a {{convert|25000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} stable there, at the cost of $200,000. It was completed in 1903. The stable, which was {{convert|250|ft}} long and {{convert|125|ft}} wide and two stories tall "with numerous towers and cupolas", had 22 box stalls and 9 straight stalls, a {{convert|75|ft|adj=on}} outdoor training ring, a {{convert|40|ft|adj=on}}-by-{{convert|50|ft|adj=on}} sleigh room, feed rooms, a hayloft, and a 5,000 bushel zinc-lined [[granary]]. It also had a gymnasium, a blacksmith shop with forge, a trophy room to display Billings' awards from the amateur races he won, and two five-room suites of living quarters. The interior was designed in oak and Georgia pine. The stable had steam heat, electric light, and hot water, all provided by its dynamo room. About twenty-five men were employed.<ref name=harness />
Nearby the stable was a 14-room {{convert|50|ft|adj=on}}-by-{{convert|100|ft|adj=on}} lodge for guests, which featured an {{convert|80|ft|adj=on}}-tall observation tower.<ref name=harness>Staff (March 22, 1903) [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/svc/tmach/v1/refer?res=9B01E6DD1F3DEE32A25751C2A9659C946297D6CF&pdf=true "The Light Harness Horse: Luxury Stables for C. K. G. Billings's Blooded Stock"] ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref>
The site was conveniently near to the [[Harlem Speedway]], built in 1894-89<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/13/realestate/a-roadway-built-for-the-elite-to-trot-out-their-rigs.html|title=A Roadway Built for the Elite to Trot Out Their Rigs|last=Gray|first=Christopher|authorlink=Christopher Gray|date=July 13, 1997|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=September 15, 2017|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1894/02/06/archives/cheers-from-unemployed-1500-saw-mayor-gilroy-begin-work-on-the.html|title=Cheers from the Unemployed: 1,500 Saw Mayor Gilroy Begin Work on the Speedway|date=February 6, 1894|author=Staff|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=September 15, 2017|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1898/07/03/archives/harlem-speedway-opened-pronounced-by-horsemen-to-be-the-finest.html|title=Harlem Speedway Opened; Pronounced by Horsemen to be the Finest Driveway for Light Speeding in the Country|date=July 3, 1898|author=Staff|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=September 15, 2017|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> for the exclusive use of riders on horseback and horse-drawn carriages. It ran from [[155th Street (Manhattan)|West 155th Street]] to [[Dyckman Street]]. Rich New Yorkers used the Speedway to train their horses and size up those of their friends and competitors.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=mcny>{{cite web |last = Robinson |first = Lauren |url = http://mcnyblog.org/2012/02/28/how-harlem-river-speedway-became-harlem-river-drive/ |title = How Harlem River Speedway Became Harlem River Drive |publisher = [[Museum of the City of New York]] |date = February 28, 2012 }}</ref> The Speedway was eventually paved and became the beginning of the [[Harlem River Drive]].<ref name=mcny /><ref>{{cite news|title=Autos to Use Speedway: Gallatin Will Open Harlem Drive to Passenger Machines Today|author=Staff|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1919/12/04/archives/autos-to-use-speedway-gallatin-will-open-harlem-drive-to-passenger.html|accessdate=July 16, 2017|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 4, 1919}}</ref>
[[File:billingsparty.jpg|350px|thumb|left|Billings' horse party]]
=== Dinner on horseback === Billings wished to celebrate the completion of his trotting stable, and his selection to be the head of the New York Equestrian Club, by giving a dinner for 36 of his male horse-riding friends in the stable on March 29, 1903. He engaged the noted restaurateur [[Louis Sherry]] to cater the event, but to avoid reporters who staked out the estate after news of the dinner had spread, Billings changed the venue at Sherry's suggestion to the grand ballroom of Sherry's restaurant at [[Fifth Avenue]] and [[44th Street (Manhattan)|44th Street]]. The ballroom had been decorated to look like an English country estate, complete with imitation brooks. Wanting he and his guests to be mounted on horses while they ate, the floor was covered with turf. The horses, which were docile animals rented from nearby riding academies, were brought to the fourth-floor ballroom via the freight elevator. The participants, arranged in a circle, ate from specially built silver trays which were attached to their saddles and drank through rubber tubes connected to iced bottles of champagne in their saddlebags. The waiters, one for each diner, served the numerous courses dressed as if grooms at a [[fox hunt]]. The 32 docile horses were each attended by an elaborately dressed groom, and near the end of the evening elaborate troughs filled with oats were brought in for the horses to eat from.<ref name="fyi" /><ref name="horseback"/><ref name=greater>{{cite greater|page=468n15}}</ref><ref name=luncheon>Staff (March 30, 1903) [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/svc/tmach/v1/refer?res=990CE1DA1E30E733A25753C3A9659C946297D6CF&pdf=true "Luncheon in a Stable"] ''[[The New York Times]]</ref>
The evening concluded with a vaudeville show.<ref name=luncheon/>
The $50,000 bill for the dinner (equivalent to ${{inflation|US|50000|1903|fmt=c}} in {{inflation-year|US}}) included the cost of a photographer from the celebrated [[Byron Company]] to document the event.<ref name="fyi">Pollak, Michael (August 15, 2004) [https://www.nytimes.com/2004/08/15/nyregion/fyi-632325.html?pagewanted=1 "F.Y.I.: For an Appetizer, Hay"] ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref><ref name="horseback">Bryk, William (March 30, 2005) [https://www.nysun.com/on-the-town/banquet-on-horseback/11409/ "Banquet on Horseback"] ''[[New York Sun]]''</ref>
Two days later, Billings officially opened his new stable with a luncheon for members of the Equestrian Club and other wealthy horsemen and dignitaries from around the country. Some rode there on horseback, but most traveled by elevated train to the 155th Street station located at the Harlem Speedway, and were conveyed to the stable by automobiles.<ref name=luncheon />
=== Billings sells his horses === In 1903, Billings, who was a prominent member of the [[Jockey Club (United States)|Jockey Club]] and was part-owner of the [[Jamaica Race Course]] in [[Jamaica, Queens]],<ref name=death /> was regarded as a "Grand Marshal" of [[harness racing]] ("trotting" or "matinee racing"),<ref>[http://matineeclub.tripod.com/BBytes/RiseandFall.html "The Rise, Decline and Fall(?) of Matinee Racing"] Western Reserve Matinee Club</ref> but in November 1905, just two years after his stable was completed, he sold his stock of horses at [[Madison Square Garden]], saying that he proposed to go abroad for a few years. Billings held back only three horses from the sale, plus one that was withdrawn because it was lame. The sale of 18 horses brought in $46,270, with the top seller bringing in $10,500.<ref>Staff (November 24, 1905) [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1905/11/24/101250136.pdf "CKG Billings Horses sold for Big Prices"] ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref>
== Estates == [[File:Estate of C.K.G. Billings.jpg|350px|thumb|right|Tryon Hall, the Manhattan estate of C.K.G. Billings]]
=== Tryon Hall === The Billings' mansion at [[196th Street (Manhattan)|West 196th Street]] and [[Fort Washington Avenue|Fort Washington Road]]<ref name=luncheon /> was designed by [[Guy Lowell]], who enlarged the lodge which had been built as part of the stables. It was organized around a central courtyard with a fountain. Landscape architect [[Charles Downing Lay]] designed the grounds. Billings called it "Tryon Hall", after Fort Tryon, which had been located there, itself named after Sir William Tryon, who was the last Governor of the English colony of New York.<ref name=dim /><ref name=enc-nyc /> The mansion stood on one of the highest points in Manhattan, overlooking the Hudson River to the west, and the Broadway Valley to the east.
By 1907, Billings, his wife, two children, and 23 servants had moved from their Manhattan townhouse into the massive Louis XIV-style chateau, now their full-time residence. It included an observatory tower topped by an octagonal room, which had a 360-degree unobstructed view. The estate had a casino with a swimming pool, [[squash (sport)|squash court]] and [[bowling alley]] for entertaining, as well as Billings' extensive stables and an area to exercise his horses.<ref name=dim /><ref>Ferree, Barr (1911) [https://archive.org/stream/gri_33125009916061#page/n11/mode/2up ''Fort Tryon Hall: The Residence of C. K. G. Billings, Esq.: A Descriptive and Illustrative Catalogue Issued Privately by the Owner''] Washington Heights, New York.</ref>
The entrance to the estate was originally at the top of the hill, approached via [[Riverside Drive (Manhattan)|Riverside Drive]] and [[181st Street (Manhattan)|West 181st Street]], to Fort Washington Road, but the upper part of [[Riverside Drive (Manhattan)|Riverside Drive]] was completed at about the same time as Billings' mansion, and he wanted a driveway which connected the mansion directly to that section of the roadway. Unfortunately, there was a steep {{convert|100|ft|adj=on}} cliff between the road and the mansion. Billings' hired the firm of [[Buchman & Fox]] to find a solution, which they did: granite was removed from the cliff to allow a passage for a zig-zagging driveway, and the stone was then used both as a retaining wall, and for the construction of an arched viaduct that the driveway initially passed through. The arched passage became known as the "Billings Arcade". The entrance to the driveway had granite pillars that were {{convert|16|ft}} tall, which supported {{convert|20|ft|adj=on}} tall gates which were {{convert|10|ft}} wide.<ref name=dim />
The entire driveway project took a year for over a hundred workers to complete, at the cost of $250,000. It raised the overall cost of the estate to more than $2 million.<ref name=dim /> The Billings Arcade still remains as part of [[Fort Tryon Park]], as does part of the driveway, now used as a pedestrian path. Another remnant is a gardener's cottage, originally a gatehouse for the estate's upper entrance, now used for park offices. The gateposts of the driveway entrance to the estate were refurbished in 2017. The driveway no longer connects to the roadway which was once Riverside Drive and is now the northbound side of the [[Henry Hudson Parkway]].
In the nearby Hudson River, Billings kept his {{convert|232|ft|m|adj=on}} yacht, ''[[TS Vanadis|Vanadis]]'' which was built in 1908.<ref name=clydeships />
Billings sold his Tryon Hall estate in 1917 to [[John D. Rockefeller, Jr.]]. His family had already moved into an apartment on Fifth Avenue and [[63rd Street (Manhattan)|63rd Street]], which has 21 rooms, and for which he paid $20,000 a year in rent. Rockefeller was assembling parcels for the creation of a park designed by the [[Olmsted Brothers]] which he planned to develop and then give to the city – this eventually became Fort Tryon Park. As part of Rockefeller's plan, he was going to tear down Tryon Hall but was held back by popular sentiment. During World War I, he offered use of the house to the U.S. government as a hospital, and was prepared to outlay $500,000 for the conversion, but this did not happen. After that, the mansion was rented to Nicolas C. Partos of the Partola Manufacturing Company, at first for the summer of 1918, but then extending for years. Partos and his family was still in residence when the building burned down on March 7, 1926.<ref name=enc-nyc>Kuhn, Jonathan "Fort Tryon Park" in {{cite enc-nyc2|page=473}}</ref><ref>Capraro, Douglas (June 10, 2014) [https://untappedcities.com/2014/06/10/the-remains-of-fort-tryon-parks-turn-of-the-century-mansion-near-the-cloisters/ "The Remains of Fort Tryon Park’s Turn of the Century Mansion Near the Cloisters"] ''Untapped Cities''</ref><ref name=dim>Miller, Tom (October 21, 2013) [http://daytoninmanhattan.blogspot.com/2013/10/the-lost-billings-mansion-tryon-hall.html "The Lost Billings Mansion -- 'Tryon Hall'"] ''Daytonian in Manhattan''</ref><ref>Staff (March 7, 1926) [https://www.nytimes.com/1926/03/07/archives/billings-mansion-destroyed-by-fire-loss-near-1000000-chateau-owned.html "Billings Mansion Destroyed by Fire"] ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref>
=== Farnsworth === After leaving Tryon Hall, Billings moved to another grand estate he had built, this one called "Farnsworth", named for his mother's family,<ref name=death /> and located in [[Locust Valley, New York]], on [[Long Island]]. It was again designed by Guy Lowell, this time in the [[Georgian Revival architecture|Georgian Revival style]], with the landscaping of the extensive grounds designed by Andrew Robeson Sargent of Boston. The buildings alone on the estate cost $1,550,000 in 1915. Although Georgian in style, Lowell designed it to be similar to an Italian villa, in that the mansion was built around a patio at its center. The house featured 11 master bedrooms with 9 baths and 19 servants bedrooms with 4 baths. The appointments were expensive and luxurious.<ref name=pudding>[http://halfpuddinghalfsauce.blogspot.com/2013/09/farnsworth-long-island-home-of-c-k-g.html "'Farnsworth' The Long Island Home of C. K. G. Billings, Esq., at Locust Valley — A Country Estate in Every Respect Perfectly Appointed] on ''The Country House'' website (September 27, 2013)</ref>
Despite the grandeur of the surrounding, Billings did not stay in Farnsworth any longer than he had in Tryon Hall. With World War 1 raging, and his health failing, Farnsworth began to sell off his East Coast properties in preparation for moving to California.<ref name=pudding /><ref name=hervey />
Billings moored his yacht ''Vanadis'' in the nearby waters. In 1916, he had sold the original ''Vanadis'' to [[Morton F. Plant House|Morton F. Plant]] in return for the smaller yacht ''[[Kanawha (1899)|Kanawha]]'', after the ''Vanadis'' struck the steamship ''Bunker Hill'', killing two people.<ref name=death /><ref name=clydeships>[http://www.clydeships.co.uk/view.php?ref=10055#v Vanadis"] ''Scottish Built Shps''</ref> In 1924, Billings ordered a second, larger yacht – {{convert|246|ft}} long – which he also named ''[[Lady Hutton|Vanadis]]''.<ref>[http://www.faktaomfartyg.se/vanadis_1924.htm ''M/S Vanadis'']</ref> This ship is now anchored at [[Riddarholmen]] in [[Stockholm]], and is now the hotel Mälardrottningen, with the ship rechristened as ''[[Lady Hutton]]'', after the actress [[Barbara Hutton]].<ref name="Hammond">{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19881123&id=HWsaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0SsEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2659,7335508 |newspaper=[[The Milwaukee Journal]] |date=November 23, 1988 |title=All Aboard: Luxury Yacht Rocks Gently at Stockholm Harbor |first1=Margo |last1=Hammond |format=PDF |pages=33, 35 |accessdate=December 13, 2014}}</ref><ref name=sun>{{cite news |first1=Brook Hill |last1=Snow |url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1987-03-15/features/8701160473_1_stockholm-lady-hutton-prices-increase |location=Stockholm, Sweden |date=March 15, 1987|title=Off The Beaten Path The Lady Hutton, One Of The World's Largest Luxury Yachts, Is Now An Elegant Hotel In Downtown Stockholm |newspaper=[[Sun Sentinel]] |accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref>Vanadis to Lady Hutton, Kajsa Karlsson, (1987)</ref>
=== Other estates === At various times, Billings also owned a {{convert|5000|acre|ha|adj=on}} estate on the [[James River]] in [[Virginia]] called [[Curles Neck Farm]], which he bought in 1913 and developed into one of the country's prime horse-breeding facilities. He had another estate in [[Colorado Springs]], [[Colorado]] and a summer home in [[Lake Geneva, Wisconsin]].<ref name=dim /><ref name=death />
When he moved to Santa Barbara, Billings had a mansion built in the hills of that city, which he called "Asombrosa". It was damaged by an earthquake in the mid-1930s, and he had another, smaller, house built nearby.<ref name=hervey />
== Later life == In 1911, Billings became the Chairman of the Board of [[Union Carbide|Union Carbide and Carbon Company]] – a company he helped to found<ref name=hervey /> – a position he held until his death in 1937. His mother died in 1913, leaving him $450,000; at that time his net worth was estimated to be $30 million,<ref name=death /> equivalent to ${{inflation|US|30|1913|fmt=c}} million in {{inflation-year|US}}. At one time he was reported to be one of the five richest men in the United States.<ref name=hervey />
Around 1915, Billings – a member of the Turf and Field Club at [[Belmont Park]]<ref name=hervey /> – was said to be the owner of the fastest stallion, mare, and [[gelding]] in the world. He was also part-owner of the [[Kentucky Derby]]-winning [[Omar Khayyam]].<ref name=death /> He was also the principal investor in the Billings Parks race track in [[Memphis, Tennessee]], which eventually closed because of anti-betting laws passed by that state. At one time he bought a controlling interest in the Kentucky Breeder's Association, which prevented that organization from going under. The association was reorganized, and Billings later donated his stock to the group.<ref name=hervey />
Billings moved to [[Santa Barbara, California]] in 1917, but maintained ownership of "Farnsworth" on Long Island, where he kept some of his horses.<ref name=death /> Others were kept at the Glenville Race Track in [[Cleveland, Ohio]].<ref name=hervey />
In 1926, Billings sold his art collection, which included works by [[Jean-Charles Cazin]], [[Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot]], [[John Crome]], [[Charles-François Daubigny]], [[Jules Dupré]], [[Charles Jacque]], [[Jean-François Millet]], [[Théodore Rousseau]], [[Constant Troyon]], and [[Félix Ziem]] for $401,300,<ref>Staff (1926) [https://archive.org/stream/famousmasterpiec00amer#page/n5/mode/2up ''Famous Masterpieces opf the French, Dutch, and English Schools: The Collection of C. K. G. Billings'' (catalog)] [[American Art Association]]</ref> in 1928 he realized $4 million for the sale of the Johnson Building, located on Exchange Street from [[Broad Street (Manhattan)|Broad Street]] to New Street. He was also part of a group of investors who built the [[Pierre Hotel]] in Manhattan, which opened in 1930.<ref name=death />
[[File:loudillon crop.jpg|325px|thumb|left|C.K.G. Billings with his horse Lou Dillon in 1903]]
After being in bad health for ten years, Billings was reported to be seriously ill on May 3, 1937, and he died from pneumonia on his estate at Billings Park, near Santa Barbara, on May 6. At the time of his death, he was still the chairman of the board of the Union Carbide Carbon Company, and was described as "one of America's wealthiest men" and "Santa Barbara's wealthiest and most philanthropic citizen."<ref name=ill>Staff (May 3, 1937) [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/svc/tmach/v1/refer?res=9F0DE7D7103AE23ABC4B53DFB366838C629EDE&pdf=true "C. K. G. Billings Seriously Ill"] ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref><ref name=death>Staff (May 7, 1937) [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/svc/tmach/v1/refer?res=940DEFDE113AE23ABC4F53DFB366838C629EDE&pdf=true "C. K. G. Billings, Noted Sportsman" (obituary)] ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref>
The funeral for Billings was held in Santa Barbara on May 8, and he was later buried in [[Graceland Cemetery]] in Chicago.<ref name=hervey />
Despite the reputation which has attached to Billings in the aftermath of the horseback dinner he was memorialized quite differently: <blockquote>Personally Mr. Billings was a man of retiring, modest, nature, who shunned the limelight except when driving or riding one of his horses upon the race course, always dressed very quietly, and in every way made himself as inconspicuous as possible. He was happiest when surrounded by the small circle of intimate friends that he best-loved ... He was the loyalest of friends and when he had once given his good will to a man it was never withdrawn unless it had been abused. His benefactions and gifts were boundless and in them, he took the greatest pleasure. In all social relations he was the reverse of pompous, arrogant or domineering, was democratic and genial and, that rarest of all things—always the same admirable and wonderful character in every spot and place, at all times and seasons and under all circumstances.<ref name=hervey /></blockquote>
== Legacy == *The Billings estate and mansion in Upper Manhattan was the setting for the [[Philo Vance]] mystery ''[[The Dragon Murder Case]]'' by [[S. S. Van Dine]].<ref name=renner>Renner, James (2007) ''Images of America: Washington Heights, Inwood, and Marble Hill''. Charleston, South Carolia: Arcadia Publishing. {{isbn|978-0-7385-5478-5}}</ref> *The CKG Billings Amateur Driving Series, is, as of 2010, a much recognized amateur American sporting event.<ref>Corban, Anthony, [http://www.harnesslink.com/www/Article.cgi?ID=4928 CKG Billings Review] August 2003, harnesslink.com</ref><ref>Knox, Tammy, [http://xwebapp.ustrotting.com/absolutenm/templates/?a=36885&z=63 Billings Amateur Trot makes stop at Hoosier Park] May 2010, ustrotting.com</ref> *[[Billings Park, Wisconsin|Billings Park]] is a neighborhood of [[Superior, Wisconsin]].
== See also == *[[Fort Tryon Park]]

{{Original research|date=March 2010}} The '''car analogy''' is a common technique used by [[engineering]] textbooks to ease the understanding of [[abstraction|abstract]] concepts in which a [[car]], its composite parts, and common circumstances surrounding it are used as [[analogy|analogs]] for elements of the conceptual [[systems]]. ==Uses of car analogies== The efficiency of car analogies reside on their capacity to explain difficult concepts (usually due to their high abstraction level) on more mundane terms with which the target audience is comfortable, and with which many also have a special interest. Due to that, car analogies appear more often on works related to [[applied sciences]] and [[technology]]. In order to work, car analogies translate [[force|agents of action]] as the car driver, the seller, or police officers; likewise, elements of a [[system]] are referred as car pieces, such as wheels, motor, or ignition keys. [[Resources]] tend to appear as gas, speed, or as the money that can be spent on better accessories/vehicles. For example, in the paragraph:
''"[[Zener diode]]s regulate voltage by acting as complementary loads, drawing more or less current as necessary to ensure a constant voltage drop across the load. This is analogous to regulating the speed of an automobile by braking rather than by varying the throttle position."''{{cite book |url=http://ibiblio.org/kuphaldt/electricCircuits/Semi/SEMI_3.html#xtocid1418812 |title=Lessons in Electric Circuits |volume=III - Semiconductors |chapter=Diodes and Rectifiers |first=Tony R |last=Kuphaldt}}
Current (resource) is depicted as the car's speed, while the role of the brakes is performed by the Zener diodes (element of the system). Car analogies are also typically used to explain the quality differences between two similar tools or hardware pieces; in that case, the best one is usually described as a [[mid-engined]] Italian [[supercar]] or a high-end [[luxury vehicle]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Engineering concepts]] [[Category:Analogy]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} '''Clock drift''' refers to several related phenomena where a [[clock]] does not run at exactly the same rate as a reference clock. That is, after some time the clock "drifts apart" or gradually desynchronizes from the other clock i.e. the crystal-based clocks used in computers, like any other clocks, subject to clock drift, which means that they count time at different rates and so they diverge. This phenomenon is used, for instance, in [[computer]]s to build [[random number generator]]s. On the negative side, clock drift can be exploited by [[timing attack]]s.
== In non-atomic clocks == {{main|Frequency drift}}
Everyday clocks such as [[watch|wristwatches]] have finite precision. Eventually they require correction to remain accurate. The rate of drift depends on the clock's quality, sometimes the stability of the power source, the ambient temperature, and other subtle environmental variables. Thus the same clock can have different drift rates at different occasions.
More advanced clocks and old mechanical clocks often have some kind of speed trimmer where one can adjust the speed of the clock and thus correct for clock drift. For instance, in [[pendulum clock]]s the clock drift can be manipulated by slightly changing the length of the [[pendulum]].
A quartz oscillator is less subject to drift due to manufacturing variances than the pendulum in a mechanical clock. Hence most everyday quartz clocks do not have an adjustable drift correction.
== Atomic clocks ==
[[Atomic clock]]s are very precise and have nearly no clock drift. Even the [[Earth's rotation|Earth's rotation rate]] has more drift and variation in drift than an atomic clock due to [[tidal acceleration]] and other effects. The principle behind the atomic clock has enabled scientists to re-define the [[SI unit]] [[second]] in terms of exactly 9 192 631 770 oscillations of the [[caesium]] atom. The precision of these oscillations allows atomic clocks to drift roughly only one second in a hundred million years; currently, the most accurate of which loses one second every 15 billion years.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Vincent|first1=James|title=The most accurate clock ever built only loses one second every 15 billion years|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/4/22/8466681/most-accurate-atomic-clock-optical-lattice-strontium|website=The Verge|accessdate=17 September 2016|date=22 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Gibney|first1=Elizabeth|title=Hyper-precise atomic clocks face off to redefine time|url=http://www.nature.com/news/hyper-precise-atomic-clocks-face-off-to-redefine-time-1.17689|website=Nature|accessdate=17 September 2016|pages=16–17|doi=10.1038/522016a|date=4 June 2015}}</ref> The [[International Atomic Time]] (TAI) [[time standard]] and its derivatives (such as the [[Coordinated Universal Time]] (UTC)) are based on [[weighted average]]s of atomic clocks worldwide.
== Relativity ==
As [[Albert Einstein|Einstein]] predicted, relativistic effects can also cause clock drift due to [[time dilation]]. This is because there is no fixed universal time, time being relative to the observer. [[Special relativity]] describes how two clocks held by observers in different [[Inertial frame of reference|inertial frames]] (i.e. moving with respect to each other but not accelerating or decelerating) will each appear to either observer to tick at different rates.
In addition to this, [[general relativity]] gives us [[gravitational time dilation]]. Briefly, a clock in a stronger gravitational field (e.g. closer to a planet) will appear to tick more slowly. People holding these clocks (i.e. those inside and outside the stronger field) would all agree on which clocks appear to be going faster.
Note that it is time itself rather than the function of the clock which is affected. Both effects have been experimentally observed.{{Citation needed|date=August 2016}}
Time dilation is of practical importance. For instance, the clocks in [[Global Positioning System|GPS satellites]] experience this effect due to the reduced gravity they experience (making their clocks appear to run more quickly than those on Earth) and must therefore incorporate relativistically corrected calculations when reporting locations to users. If general relativity were not accounted for, a navigational fix based on the GPS satellites would be false after only 2 minutes, and errors in global positions would continue to accumulate at a rate of about 10 kilometers each day.<ref>Pogge, Richard W.; [http://www.astronomy.ohio-state.edu/~pogge/Ast162/Unit5/gps.html "Real-World Relativity: The GPS Navigation System"] Accessed 30 June 2012.</ref>
== Random number generators == {{see also|Hardware random number generator#Clock drift}} {{Unreferenced section|date=November 2008}} [[Computer program]]s often need high quality random numbers, especially for [[cryptography]]. There are several similar ways clock drift can be used to build [[random number generator]]s (RNGs).
One way to build a [[hardware random number generator#Clock drift|hardware random number generator]] is to use two independent [[Crystal oscillator|clock crystals]], one that for instance ticks 100 times per second and one that ticks 1 million times per second. On average the faster crystal will then tick 10,000 times for each time the slower one ticks. But since clock crystals are not precise, the exact number of ticks will vary. That variation can be used to create random bits. For instance, if the number of fast ticks is even, a 0 is chosen, and if the number of ticks is odd, a 1 is chosen. Thus such a 100/1000000 RNG circuit can produce 100 somewhat random bits per second. Typically such a system is biased—it might for instance produce more zeros than ones—and so hundreds of somewhat-random bits are [[decorrelation|"whitened"]] to produce a few unbiased bits.
There is also a similar way to build a kind of "software random number generator". This involves comparing the timer tick of the operating system (the tick that usually is 100–1000 times per second) and the speed of the [[Central processing unit|CPU]]. If the OS timer and the CPU run on two independent clock crystals the situation is ideal and more or less the same as the previous example. But even if they both use the same clock crystal the [[Process (computing)|process]]/program that does the clock drift measurement is "disturbed" by many more or less unpredictable events in the CPU such as [[interrupt]]s and other processes and programs that runs at the same time. Thus the measurement will still produce fairly good random numbers. Some argue{{Who|date=July 2009}} they are then not true random numbers but they seem to be good enough for most needs.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}}
Most hardware random number generators such as the ones described above are fairly slow. Therefore, most programs only use them to create a good seed that they then feed to a [[pseudorandom number generator]] or a [[cryptographically secure pseudorandom number generator]] to produce many random numbers fast.
== Timing attack ==
In 2006, a [[side channel attack]] was published<ref> Steven J. Murdoch. ''Hot or Not: Revealing Hidden Services by their Clock Skew'', ACM CCS 2006. [http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/~sjm217/papers/ccs06hotornot.pdf (pdf)]</ref> that exploited clock skew based on CPU heating. The attacker causes heavy CPU load on a [[pseudonymity|pseudonymous]] server ([[Tor hidden service]]), causing CPU heating. CPU heating is correlated with clock skew, which can be detected by observing timestamps (under the server's real identity).
== See also ==
* [[Bit slip]] * [[Clock skew]] * [[Effects of relativity on GPS]] * [[Injection locking]] * [[Segal's law]]

{{globalize|date=September 2014}} [[File:Universal Contactless Card Symbol.svg|thumb|250px|right|EMV contactless symbol used on compatible payment terminals]] [[File:Americanexpressplatinumemvcontactless.jpg|thumb|right|A contactless enabled American Express charge card issued in the UK]] '''Contactless payment''' systems are [[credit card]]s and [[debit card]]s, [[key fob]]s, [[smart card]]s, or other devices, including [[smartphone]]s and other [[mobile device]]s, that use [[radio-frequency identification]] (RFID) or [[near field communication]] (NFC, e.g. [[Samsung Pay]], [[Apple Pay]], [[Google Pay]], Fitbit Pay, or any bank mobile application that support Contactless) for making secure payments. The embedded chip and antenna enable consumers to wave their card, fob, or handheld device over a [[Credit card terminal|reader]] at the [[point of sale]] terminal. Contactless payments are made in close physical proximity, unlike [[mobile payments]] which use broad-area cellular or [[WiFi]] networks and do not involve close physical proximity.
Some suppliers claim that transactions can be almost twice as fast as a conventional [[cash]], credit, or debit card purchase. Because no [[signature]] or [[PIN number|PIN]] verification is typically required, contactless purchases are typically limited to small value sales. Lack of authentication provides a window during which [[credit card fraud|fraudulent purchases]] can be made while the card owner is unaware of the card's loss.
In 2012, MasterCard Advisors wrote that consumers are likely to spend more money using their cards due to the ease of small transactions.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://newsroom.mastercard.com/press-releases/new-mastercard-advisors-study-on-contactless-payments-shows-almost-30-lift-in-total-spend-within-first-year-of-adoption/|title= New MasterCard Advisors Study on Contactless Payments Shows Almost 30% Lift in Total Spend Within First Year of Adoption|accessdate=2013-03-13|work=newsroom.mastercard.com|date=2012-05-03}}</ref> [[MasterCard]] Canada says it has seen "about 25 percent" higher spending by users of its [[MasterCard Contactless|Mastercard Contactless]]-brand RFID credit cards.<ref>Dubinsky, Zach. [http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/new-credit-cards-pose-security-problem-1.904220 "New credit cards pose security problem"]. CBCNews.ca. 2010-06-02. Retrieved 2010-06-03.</ref> [[EMV]] is a common standard used by major credit card and smartphone companies for use in general commerce. [[Contactless smart card]]s that function as [[stored-value card]]s are becoming popular for use as [[transit system]] [[Public transport#Electronic fare card|farecards]], such as the [[Oyster card]] or [[RioCard]]. These can often store non-currency value (such as monthly passes) in additional to fare value purchased with cash or electronic payment.
==History== [[Mobil]] was one of the most notable early adopters of a similar technology, and offered their "[[Speedpass]]" contactless payment system for participating [[Mobil]] gas stations as early as 1997. Although Mobil has since merged with Exxon, the service is still offered at many of [[ExxonMobil]]'s stations. [[Freedompay]] also had early wins in the contactless space with [[Bank of America]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://secureidnews.com/news-item/freedompay-makes-waves-in-contactless-payment/|title=FreedomPay makes waves in contactless payment - SecureIDNews|publisher=}}</ref> and [[McDonald's]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/tech/news/2001-05-29-mcdonalds-e-payments.htm | work=USA Today | title=McDonald's testing e-payment system | date=2001-05-29}}</ref>
[[McDonald's]], [[KFC]], [[Burger King]], [[Boots UK|Boots]], [[Eat (restaurant)|Eat]], [[Heron Foods]], [[Pret a Manger]], [[Stagecoach Group]], [[Subway (restaurant)|Subway]], [[AMT Coffee]], [[Tesco]], [[Asda]] and [[Lidl]] are among the retailers offering contactless payments to their customers in the UK. In March 2008, [[Eat (restaurant)|Eat]] became the first restaurant chain to adopt contactless.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.paymentsnews.com/2008/03/first-fully-int.html|title= First Fully Integrated Contactless Payment System in UK|accessdate=2012-08-26|work =www.paymentnews.com|date= 2008-03-26}}</ref>
Major financial entities now offering contactless payment systems include [[MasterCard]], [[Citibank]], [[JPMorgan Chase]], [[American Express]], [[KeyBank]], [[Barclays]], [[Barclaycard]], [[HSBC]], [[Lloyds Banking Group]], [[FreedomPay]], [[The Co-operative Bank]], [[Nationwide Building Society]] and [[The Royal Bank of Scotland Group]]. [[Visa Inc.#payWave|Visa payWave]], American Express Expresspay, and [[MasterCard#MasterCard Contactless|MasterCard Contactless]] are examples of contactless credit cards which have become widespread in the U.S. and UK.
The first contactless cards in the UK were issued by Barclaycard in 2007.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.finextra.com/newsarticle/17411/barclaycard-rolls-out-oyster-payments-card|title=Barclaycard rolls out Oyster payments card|last=|first=|date=September 2007|website=Finextra|publisher=Finextra|access-date=}}</ref> {{As of|2014|12}}, there are approximately 58 million contactless-enabled cards in use, in the UK, and over 147,000 terminals in use though this is growing in numbers and percentages of adoption.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Campbell|first1=Francis|title=Contactless payments taking off in the UK in 2015|url=http://www.mobiletransaction.org/contactless-payments-uk/|website=mobiletransaction.org|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.contactless.info/Facts-and-Stats.asp |title=Key Facts and Stats|accessdate=August 6, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100721223225/http://www.contactless.info/Facts-and-Stats.asp |archivedate=July 21, 2010 }}</ref>
Telecom operators are starting to get involved in contactless payments via the use of [[near field communication]] phones. [[Belgacom]]'s [[Pingping (payment)|Pingping]], for example, has a stored value account and via a partnership with [[Alcatel-Lucent]]'s [[Touchatag]] provides contactless payment functionalities. In January 2010, Barclaycard partnered with mobile phone firm [[Orange (telecommunications)|Orange]], to launch a contactless credit card in the UK.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.home.barclaycard/news/barclaycard-orange-partnership.html|title=Orange and Barclaycard deliver next step in their partnership with contactless co-branded credit card|last=|first=|date=January 2010|website=Barclaycard|publisher=Barclaycard|access-date=}}</ref> Orange and Barclaycard also announced in 2009 that they would be launching a mobile phone with contactless technology.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/mediatechnologyandtelecoms/telecoms/4958655/Barclaycard-and-Orange-unveil-pay-by-mobile-service.html|title= Barclaycard and Orange unveil pay-by-mobile service by Garry White|accessdate=2010-08-06 |work= Daily Telegraph|publisher= |date= 2009-03-08 |location=London}}</ref>
In October 2011, the first mobile phones with MasterCard PayPass and/or Visa payWave certification appeared. A PayPass or payWave account can be assigned to the embedded secure element and/or SIM card within the phones. [[Google Pay]] is an application for devices running Google's Android OS, which allows users to make purchases using [[Near field communication|NFC]], which initially required a physical secure element but this was replaced by [[host card emulation]] which was introduced in Android 4.4 (KitKat). [[Softcard]] (formerly known as Isis mobile wallet), Cityzi and Quick Tap wallets for example, use a secure SIM card to store encrypted personal information. Contactless payments with enabled mobile phones still occur on a small scale, but every month an increasing number of mobile phones are certified.<ref>{{cite web|title=Certified phones|url=http://www.nfc-phones.org/certified-phones/|publisher=nfc-phones.org|accessdate=2015-02-07}}</ref>
In February 2014, MasterCard announced that it would partner with Weve, which is a joint venture between [[EE (telecommunications company)|EE]], [[Telefónica UK]], and [[Vodafone UK]], to focus on mobile payments. The partnership will promote the development of "contactless mobile payment systems" by creating a universal platform in Europe for it.<ref>Villarreal, Alexandra. [http://bankcreditnews.com/payment-technology/mastercard-weve-partner-accelerate-contactless-payments-shift-u-k/15565/ "MasterCard, Weve partner to accelerate contactless payments shift in U.K."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160117121754/http://bankcreditnews.com/payment-technology/mastercard-weve-partner-accelerate-contactless-payments-shift-u-k/15565/ |date=2016-01-17 }} ''Bank Credit News''. 2/10/2014. Retrieved 2/10/2014.</ref>
In September 2014, [[Transport for London]]'s Tube began accepting contactless payment. The number of completed contactless journeys has now exceeded 300m. On Friday 18 December, the busiest single day in 2015, a record 1.24m journeys were completed by over 500k unique contactless cards.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.home.barclaycard/contactless/contactless-has-caught-on-underground.html|title=Contactless has caught on underground|last=|first=|date=February 2016|website=Barclaycard|publisher=Barclaycard|access-date=}}</ref>
In 2016 [[Erste Group]] launched an NFC only debit card implemented as a sticker in Austria. It can be used at any NFC supporting terminal for transactions of unlimited amount however for transactions over the floor limit of 25 EUR a PIN is required to confirm the transaction.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sparkasse.at/erstebank/Privatkunden/Konto-karten/BankCard-NFC/Sticker|title=BankCard Sticker|last=|first=|date=January 2016|website=Erste Bank und Sparkassen|publisher=Erste Bank Group|access-date=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822043548/https://www.sparkasse.at/erstebank/Privatkunden/Konto-karten/BankCard-NFC/Sticker|archivedate=2016-08-22|df=}}</ref>
In 2016, contactless payments start to become even broader with [[wearable technology]] devices also offering this payment feature.
In 2018, the Westpac Banking Corporation in Australia revealed contactless payment statistics from 2017 and claimed in the report that contactless payments approached saturation point by being used in over 90% of purchases. The Australian St.George Bank reported 94.6% usage for the same period.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.westpac.com.au/personal-banking/credit-cards/explore/visa-contactless-payments-data/|title=Contactless Payments Statistics Australia 2017 {{!}} Westpac|website=www.westpac.com.au|language=en|access-date=2018-07-09}}</ref>
==Security== Depending on the economic space, there may be a payment limit on single transactions, and some contactless cards can only be used a certain number of times before customers are asked for their PIN.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lloydsbank.com/current-accounts/debit-card/contactless.asp|title=Lloyds Bank - UK Bank Accounts - Contactless Debit Cards|publisher=}}</ref> Contactless debit and credit transactions use the same [[chip and PIN]] network as older cards and are protected by the same fraud guarantees. Where PIN is supported, the contactless part of the card remains non-functional until a standard [[chip and PIN]] transaction has been executed.<ref>https://tfl.gov.uk/fares-and-payments/contactless/my-card-doesn-t-work</ref> This provides some verification that the card was delivered to the actual cardholder.
Under fraud guarantee standards U.S. banks are liable for any fraudulent transactions charged to the contactless cards.{{Verify source|date=January 2018}}
==Floor limit== Because no [[signature]] or [[PIN number|PIN]] verification is typically required, contactless purchases are typically limited to a set maximum amount per transaction, known as a ''[[floor limit]]''. Limits may vary between banks. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Economic space !! Limit !! Comment |- | Australia || No limit || For transactions over A$100 a PIN is required.<ref>{{cite web|title=MasterCard® contactless|url=http://www.mastercard.com.au/contactless.html|website=MasterCard|publisher=MasterCard Australia|accessdate=18 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Visa payWave: FAQs|url=http://www.visa.com.au/cardholders/cardsservices/visa_paywave_faqs.shtml#q9|website=Visa Australia|publisher=Visa|accessdate=18 February 2016}}</ref> |- | Austria || No limit || For transactions exceeding €25 a PIN is required. Additionally for cards produced before 2017 only five transactions can be made without a PIN.<ref>{{cite web|title=Maestro® kontraktlos|url=http://www.maestrocard.com/at/privatkunden/innovation_kontaktlos.html|website=Maestro|publisher=Maestro Austria|accessdate=4 July 2016}}</ref> Cards issued after December 2016 need a PIN code for transactions over €25 or a contactless total of €125. |- | Bangladesh|| BDT3000.00 || For transactions over BDT3000.00 a PIN is required. |- | Belgium || No limit || For transactions over €25 a PIN is required. When several contactless payments in a row reach the amount of €50, the PIN is required. |- | Brazil || No limit || For transactions over R$50,00 a PIN is required. |- | Bulgaria || No limit || For transactions over 25 BGN (~€12) a PIN is required. |- | Canada || CA$100 || Limits are completely at the discretion of the merchant's acquiring bank and the consumer's bank. There is no law limiting the amounts. However financial institutions limit contactless payments to $CA100. |- | Chile || $12.000 CLP || |- | China || CN¥1000<ref>http://www.unionpayintl.com/en/enaboutUpi/ennewsCenter/encompanyNews/3002674.shtml</ref> || UnionPay QuickPass. PIN required unless disabled with bank. |- | Croatia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pbzcard.hr/hr/prihvat-kartica/beskontaktno-placanje|title=Beskontaktno plaćanje - Prihvat kartica - PBZCard.hr|publisher=}}</ref>|| No limit || For transactions over 100HRK PIN or signature are needed. |- | Czech Republic ||No limit||For transactions over 500 CZK PIN is needed. For every 3 consecutive contactless transactions PIN is needed. |- | Denmark<ref>[http://www.nets.eu/dk-da/Om/nyheder-og-presse/Pages/Dankortet-bliver-nu-kontaktl%C3%B8st.aspx?intcmp=dk-forside-spot-Dankort-kontaktl%C3%B8st "Dankortet bliver nu kontaktløst"] {{dead link|date=August 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>|| No limit ||For transactions over 350 DKK PIN is needed. Sometimes PIN is needed anyway to ensure the card is used by its owner. |- | Dominican Republic || No Limit || |- | Eurozone || €25 || In general{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} |- | Estonia<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.swedbank.ee/viipemakse/eng/|title=Swedbank|website=Swedbank|accessdate = 2017-01-02}}</ref>|| €25 || |- | Finland || €25 || |- | France || €30 || Can be used up to three times a day. Cannot be used for transactions over €30. |- | Germany || €25 || For each transaction over €25 or €50 (some Visa cards) a PIN or CDCVM verification is required. |- |Greece |€25 |For transactions over €25 a PIN is required |- | Hong Kong || No limit || Initially banks, not government, set it for $500 or under, then (for some banks) under $1000 (HKD), until the limits were removed. |- | Hungary || No limit || For transactions over 5000 HUF PIN is needed. For every 10 consecutive contactless transactions or if you reach 10.000 HUF PIN is needed. |- | Iceland ||ISK 5.000||Íslandsbanki has a lower limit of ISK 4.200. For each transaction over the limit, Chip and PIN are required. Also, a cumulative limit of ISK 10.000 between Chip and PIN uses. |- | India ||Rs. 2000||Above Rs. 2000 Contact chip transaction needs to be done. |- | Ireland ||€30||Previously €15 until 1 October 2015. |- | Italy ||€25|| For transactions over €25 PIN is needed |- | Japan || JP¥20000 || JCB QUICPay and QUICPay＋<ref>{{cite web|title=JCB QUICPay|url=http://www.jcb.co.jp/card/add/quicpay/|accessdate=5 September 2017}}</ref> |- | Latvia || €25 || |- | Lithuania<ref>{{Cite web|title = Contactless cards|url = https://ib.swedbank.lt/private/d2d/cards/bankCards/contactless|website=Swedbank|accessdate = 2016-09-01}}</ref> || €25 || |- | Macedonia, Republic of || 750 MKD || |- | Malaysia || RM250 || Cumulative limits (total amount and/or consecutive transactions) differ between card issuers.<ref>{{cite web|title=FAQs on migration to PIN-based payment cards|url=http://www.bnm.gov.my/documents/2016/faq_migration_pin_based.pdf|publisher=[[Bank Negara Malaysia]]|accessdate=9 February 2018|page=2|date=28 October 2016}}</ref> By default, for each transaction above RM250 PIN is required. But the limit is customizable. <ref>{{cite web|author=John Lim|title=How to disable contactless payment?|url=http://says.com/my/lifestyle/disable-contactless-payment|publisher=says.com}}</ref> |- | Netherlands<ref>{{Cite web|title = Mijlpaal: 100 miljoen contactloze betalingen {{!}} CCV Holland|url = https://www.ccv.nl/nieuws/overzicht/100-miljoen-contactloze-betalingen|website = www.ccv.nl|accessdate = 2015-11-20}}</ref> || No limit || For card payments of more than €25 at once or €50 in a row a PIN is required. Some older cards only allow five transactions in a row without PIN. Most retailers have terminals that support CDCVM as verification (i.e. Apple Pay). While some banks already offer Android NFC/Tap&Pay, both service's are supported. Also note that broad acceptance of creditcards isn't commonplace yet, so that's up to the individual merchant. |- | New Zealand || No limit ||For each transaction over NZ$80 a PIN is required. |- | Norway || 200 NOK ||For each transaction over 200 NOK a PIN is required. |- | Poland || No limit || For transactions over or equal to 50 PLN PIN is required. |- | Portugal || €20 || |- | Romania || No limit || For transactions over or equal to 100 lei PIN is required. |- | Russia || No limit || For transactions over ₽1000 PIN or signature is required. |- | Saudi Arabia || 100 SR per transaction (3 max) || For every 3 consecutive contactless transactions PIN is required. |- | Serbia || No limit || For more than 2000RSD PIN verification is mandatory |- | Singapore || S$ 100 || The current transaction limit for contactless payments in Singapore is [[Singapore dollar|S$]]100, although some banks offer higher<ref name=StraitsTimes>{{cite newspaper|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/business/banking/nets-payments-to-go-digital-and-contactless|title=Nets payments to go digital and contactless|newspaper=The Straits Times|date=8 February 2017|first=Rachel|last=Boon|accessdate=25 August 2017}}</ref>. |- | Slovakia || No limit || For transactions over €20 PIN is needed. For every 3 consecutive contactless transactions PIN is needed. |- | Slovenia || No limit || For transactions over €15 PIN is needed. |- | South Africa || 500 ZAR || Increased to R500 in May 2017 (except for [[Absa bank|ABSA]] Bank which remained at R200)<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businesslive.co.za/bt/money/2017-11-18-tap-n-go-not-as-risky-as-many-fear/|title='Tap 'n go' not as risky as many fear|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en-US}}</ref> |- | Spain || No limit || For more than €20 PIN verification is mandatory |- | Sri Lanka || No Limit || For more than LKR 5000 PIN/signature verification is required |- | Sweden || 200 SEK || For each transaction over 200 SEK a PIN is required. |- | Switzerland || 40 CHF || For transactions over 40 CHF a PIN is required. |- | Taiwan || No limit || Signatures may be required for large purchases. |- | Thailand || ฿1500 || |- | Turkey || 90 TL || Transactions over 90 TL require PIN entry. |- | Ukraine || No limit ||For transactions over 100 UAH a PIN is required |- | United Kingdom || £30 || £20 until 1 September 2015;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-34110348|title=Contactless card limit rises to £30 as card use surges|date=1 September 2015|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> still £20 limit on some cards. Sometimes PIN is needed anyway to ensure the card is used by its owner. Some retailers will allow higher value purchases using newer hardware that supports high value purchases if the contactless authentication method is biometric (e.g. Apple Touch ID used in Apple Pay)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.knowyourmobile.com/ios/apple-pay/23175/apple-pay-100-backed-uks-major-banks-including-barclays|title=Apple Pay 100% Backed By UK's Major Banks -- Including Barclays|website=Know Your Mobile|access-date=2016-05-04}}</ref> |- | United States of America || No limit || |}

revision.comment: /* History and politics */
revision.text:
[[Image:PAL and D2-MAC Transmission.png|thumb|The simultaneous [[PAL]] transmission of all TV-picture elements and the multiplexed transmission of the TV picture elements with D2-MAC.]] [[Image:Multiplexed_Analogue_Components_transmission_(simulation).jpg|thumb|Simulated MAC signal. From left to right: digital data, chrominance and luminance]] [[Image:D2-MAC processing.png|thumb|D2-Mac processing on a Philips satellite receiver from 1990]] '''D2-MAC''' is a [[satellite television]] transmission standard, a member of [[Multiplexed Analogue Components]] family. It was created to solve [[D-MAC]]'s bandwidth problem on European cable systems. * D2-MAC uses half the data rate of [[D-MAC]] {{nowrap|(10.125 Mbit/s)}} * D2-MAC has a reduced vision bandwidth, about 1/2 that of D-MAC. * D2-MAC retains most of the quality of a [[D-MAC]] signal—but consumes only 5 MHz of bandwidth.
== Technical details == MAC transmits luminance and chrominance data separately in time rather than separately in frequency (as other analog television formats do, such as composite video).
Audio and Scrambling (selective access) * Audio, in a format similar to [[NICAM]] was transmitted digitally rather than as an FM sub-carrier. * The MAC standard included a standard scrambling system, [[EuroCrypt]], a precursor to the standard DVB-CSA encryption system.
==History and politics== MAC was developed by the UK's [[Independent Broadcasting Authority]] (IBA) and in 1982 was adopted as the transmission format for the UK's forthcoming [[direct broadcast satellite]] (DBS) television services (eventually provided by [[British Satellite Broadcasting]]). The following year MAC was adopted by the [[European Broadcasting Union]] (EBU) as the standard for all DBS.
By 1986, despite there being two standards, D-MAC and D2-MAC, favoured by different countries in Europe, an EU Directive imposed MAC on the national DBS broadcasters, to provide a stepping stone from analogue [[PAL]] and [[SECAM]] formats to the eventual [[High-definition television|high definition]] and [[digital TV|digital]] television of the future, with European TV manufacturers in a privileged position to provide the equipment required.
However, the [[SES Astra|Astra]] satellite system was also starting up at this time (the first satellite, [[Astra 1A]] was launched in 1989) and that operated outside of the EU’s MAC requirements, due to being a non-DBS satellite. Despite further pressure from the EU (including a further Directive originally intended to make MAC provision compulsory in TV sets, and a subsidy to broadcasters to use the MAC format), most broadcasters outside Scandinavia preferred the lower cost of PAL transmission and receiving equipment.
In the 2000s, the use of D-MAC and D2-MAC ceased when the satellite broadcasts of the channels concerned changed to DVB-S format.<ref>''High Above'' Broadgate Publications (April, 2010).</ref>
== See also == * [[Analog high-definition television systems]] * [[PAL]] & [[SECAM]] * [[Multiplexed Analogue Components]] * [[DVB-S]] & [[DVB-T]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.stjarnhimlen.se/tv/tv.html#MAC Multiplexed Analogue Components] in "Analog TV Broadcast Systems" by Paul Schlyter * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_a7Z_eRiBUM Example of a raw D2-MAC transmission being received]

'''Evernote''' is a [[mobile app]] designed for [[Note-taking|note taking]], organizing, task lists, and archiving.<ref name="brain">{{cite web |title=Inside Evernote’s brain |url=https://www.fastcompany.com/90216018/inside-evernotes-brain |author=McCracken, Harry |website=FastCompany.com |publisher=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]] |date=Aug 14, 2018 |access-date=Aug 15, 2018}}</ref> It is developed by the Evernote Corporation, headquartered in [[Redwood City, California]]. The app allows users to create notes, which can be formatted text, web pages or web page excerpts, photographs, voice memos, or handwritten "ink" notes. Notes can also have file attachments. Notes can be sorted into notebooks, [[Tag (metadata)|tagged]], annotated, edited, given comments, searched, and exported.
Evernote is [[cross-platform]], including support for [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[Microsoft Windows]] and [[macOS]]. Evernote is free to use with monthly usage limits, and offers paid plans for expanded or lifted limits.

==Architecture== ===Coding and versions=== In 2010, the coding language for the suite was changed from [[C Sharp (programming language)|C#]] for version 3.5 to [[C++]] in version 4.0 to improve performance.<ref name="lextrait">{{cite web|url=http://www.lextrait.com/Vincent/implementations.html |title=The Programming Languages Beacon |first=Vincent |last=Lextrait |date=December 2013 |access-date=July 21, 2015 |edition=13.0 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120530/http://www.lextrait.com/Vincent/implementations.html |archivedate=May 30, 2012 |df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://blog.evernote.com/blog/2010/10/26/evernote-4-for-windows-is-here/|title = Evernote 4 for Windows is here!|date = October 26, 2010|access-date = July 21, 2015|website = Evernote Blog|publisher = Evernote Corporation|last = Constantinou|first = Philip|type = blog}}{{Self-published inline|date = July 2015|certain = yes}}</ref>
===Data entry=== As well as the keyboard entry of typed notes, Evernote supports image capture from cameras on supported devices, and the recording of voice notes. In some situations, text that appears in captured images can be recognized using [[Optical character recognition|OCR]] and [[Web annotation|annotated]]. Evernote also supports touch and tablet screens with [[handwriting recognition]]. Evernote web-clipping plugins are available for the most popular Internet browsers that allow marked sections of webpages to be captured and clipped to Evernote. If no section of a webpage has been highlighted, Evernote can clip the full page. Evernote also supports the ability to e-mail notes to the service, allowing for automated note entry via e-mail rules or filters.<ref>Westfall, Jonathan. [http://jonwestfall.com/2010/09/scan-directly-from-your-office-to-evernote/ Scan Directly from your Office to Evernote] ''JonWestfall.com'', September 28, 2010. (Accessed July 18, 2011)</ref>
Where suitable hardware is available, Evernote can automatically add geolocation tags to notes.
As of November 2018, Evernote Pro integrates directly with [[Google Drive]], [[Microsoft Outlook]], [[Microsoft Teams]], and [[Slack (software)|Slack]], and Evernote Pro adds an integration with [[Salesforce.com|Salesforce]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://evernote.com/compare-plans|title=Compare plans and get started for free {{!}} Evernote|website=Evernote|language=en|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref> All versions of Evernote also support integrations through [[IFTTT]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ifttt.com/evernote|title=IFTTT|last=IFTTT|website=ifttt.com|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref> and [[Zapier]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://zapier.com/apps/evernote/integrations/|title=Evernote Integrations|last=Zapier|website=Zapier|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref> In 2013, Evernote deprecated its direct integration with [[Twitter]]<ref name="Tweet to self: Evernote gets Twitter integration">{{cite news | url=http://m.cnet.com/news/tweet-to-self-evernote-gets-twitter-integration/10216234?ds=1 | title=Tweet to self: Evernote gets Twitter integration | work=C Net News | date=April 9, 2009 | access-date=April 1, 2013}}</ref> in favor of these third-party services.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blog.evernote.com/blog/2013/11/26/how-to-capture-your-social-media-memories-with-evernote/|title=How to Capture Your Social Media Moments with Evernote|last=|first=|date=November 26, 2013|website=The Evernote Blog|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131209171421/http://blog.evernote.com/blog/2013/11/26/how-to-capture-your-social-media-memories-with-evernote/|archive-date=December 9, 2013|dead-url=|access-date=November 2, 2018}}</ref>

====Data storage and access==== On supported operating systems, Evernote allows users to store and edit notes on their local machine,<ref>{{cite web|title=Evernote Data Usage|url=https://evernote.com/privacy/data_usage.php|website=Evernote|access-date=June 23, 2015}}</ref> using a [[SQLite]] database in Windows.<ref>http://mengwong.livejournal.com/84064.html</ref>
Users with Internet access and an Evernote account can also have their notes automatically synchronized with a master copy held on Evernote's servers. This approach lets a user access and edit their data across multiple machines and operating system platforms, but still view, input and edit data when an Internet connection is not available. However, notes stored on Evernote servers are not encrypted.
Where Evernote client software is not available, online account-holders can access their note archive via a web interface or through a media device. The service also allows selected files to be shared for viewing and editing by other users.
The Evernote software can be downloaded and used as "stand-alone" software without using the online portion of an Evernote account (online registration is required for initial setup, however), but it will not be able to upload files to the Evernote server, or use the server to synchronize or share files between different Evernote installations. Also, no image or Image-PDF (Premium only) recognition and indexing will take place if the software is used entirely offline.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}}
==Accounts== [[File:3 months Evernote Premium gift card - Evernote Taiwan User Meetup (6353586689).jpg|thumb|Evernote Premium [[gift card]].]] Evernote is a free online service that allows users to upgrade to Plus*, Premium, or a Business account. Free, Plus* and Premium Evernote accounts have a maximum limit of 100,000 notes and 250 notebooks.<ref name="help.evernote.com">{{cite web |url=https://help.evernote.com/hc/en-us/articles/209005247 |title=What are the system limits of Evernote? |access-date=June 29, 2016}}</ref>
Basic customers can upload 60 MB of data each month. Plus* customers get a 1 GB upload limit, offline notes on mobile devices, as well as passcode lock for mobile devices. Emails can also be sent to their Evernote account.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Evernote Pricing|url = https://evernote.com/pricing/|website = Evernote|access-date = May 17, 2015}}</ref>
Premium subscribers are granted 10 GB of new uploaded data every month, faster word recognition in images, heightened security, PDF annotation, Context, where notes and news articles can be seen, which are related to the open note and the ability to search text within PDF documents. They also receive additional options for notebook sharing. Each of free, Plus* and Premium account types allow notebook sharing with other Evernote users; however, the accounts are distinguished by editing capabilities. In regards to shared notebooks, editing permissions to non-paid account holders may only be granted to premium Evernote subscribers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://support.evernote.com/link/portal/16051/16058/Article/629/An-Introduction-to-Sharing |title=Evernote Support | Evernote |publisher=Support.evernote.com |date= |access-date=June 15, 2013}}</ref><ref>Premium plan information [https://www.evernote.com/about/premium/ Evernote.com] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110902041108/http://www.evernote.com/about/premium/ |date=September 2, 2011 }}</ref> The free service does not make files available offline on iOS and Android devices; while sometimes they are available from cache, editing these files can cause conflicts when synchronizing.
With the full version of Evernote Business, users sync and view work documents through a variety of platforms, such as Mac, iPhone and iPads, Web, Windows and Android Devices. Files that can be uploaded include spreadsheets, presentations, notes and design mock ups. In addition, administrators can monitor company progress and individual employees through the admin console.<ref>{{cite web|last=Knight|first=Chris|title=Evernote Aims at SMBs With New Business-Class Product|url=http://www.cmswire.com/cms/information-management/evernote-aims-at-smbs-with-new-businessclass-product-017126.php|work=CMSWire|publisher=Simpler Media Group, Inc.|access-date=January 17, 2016|date=August 24, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ingram|first=Katie|title=Evernote Business Released as a Collaboration & Communication Tool for SMBs|url=http://www.cmswire.com/cms/social-business/evernote-business-released-as-a-collaboration-communication-tool-for-smbs-018598.php|work=CMSWire|publisher=Simpler Media Group, Inc.|access-date=January 17, 2016|date=December 5, 2012}}</ref>
In June 2016, Evernote announced the limitation for users of its free Basic account to two devices per year and raised prices for its premium service tiers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/6/28/12052056/evernote-price-changes-basic-plus-premium |title=Evernote raises prices of its paid plans, limits device sharing on free tier| work=The Verge|date=June 28, 2016|access-date=June 29, 2016}}</ref> Non-paying Evernote users are able to sync notes between two devices. Plus* lets users store notes offline and upload up to 1GB files, while Premium adds document-parsing features and 9GB of additional storage.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/mobile/evernote-free-tier-two-devices-price-hikes/ |title=Evernote restricts free accounts to two devices, increases the price of paid tiers| work= digitaltrends|date=June 28, 2016| access-date=June 29, 2016}}</ref>
From early April 2018, Evernote Plus was no longer available for purchase,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://help.evernote.com/hc/en-us/articles/209005157 |title=Which Evernote product is right for me? |access-date=August 9, 2018}}</ref> however, users who currently have the Plus subscription can maintain it as long as their subscription is still active.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://help.evernote.com/hc/en-us/articles/209005867 |title=FAQ about Evernote subscription plans: Can I subscribe to Evernote Plus? |access-date=August 9, 2018}}</ref>
==Supported platforms== [[File:Evernote iOS logo.png|thumb|100px|''Evernote for iOS'' icon]] Evernote clients are available for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[macOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[iOS]] ([[iPhone]], [[iPad]], [[iPod Touch]]), [[Windows Mobile]], [[Windows Phone]],<ref>{{cite news | author = Duffy, Jill | title = Evernote Unveils Windows Phone 7 App | url = https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2387176,00.asp | publisher = [[PC Magazine]] | date = June 17, 2011 | access-date = March 6, 2013}}</ref> [[WebOS]], [[Maemo]], [[BlackBerry]] (including [[BlackBerry Playbook]]), and [[Google Wave]] platforms as well as a beta for [[S60 (software platform)|Symbian S60]] 5th Edition. There are portable versions of Evernote available for flash drives and [[U3 (software)|U3]] drives. There is currently no officially supported native client for [[Linux]] or [[Berkeley Software Distribution|BSD]], but the company provides an API for external Linux clients.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://help.evernote.com/hc/en-us/articles/208313748-Evernote-on-Linux|title=Evernote on Linux|website=Evernote Help & Learning|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-16}}</ref>
There is substantial variation in supported features on different platforms: For example, it is possible to edit [[Rich Text Format]] and sketches on Windows; on Mac it is possible to edit rich text, but only view sketches; and on the iPad only plain text could be edited prior to version 4.1.0 (August 2011).
Web clipping support is installed by default on the [[Internet Explorer]] and [[Safari (web browser)|Safari]] browsers when the Evernote software is installed under Windows or macOS. Evernote web-clipping plugins are also available for the [[Yandex Browser]], [[Firefox]], [[Opera (web browser)|Opera]], and [[Google Chrome]] browsers, and need to be downloaded and installed separately from the respective browser.
The Evernote email-clipper is automatically installed in [[Microsoft Office Outlook]] if the desktop version is installed on the same computer. There is a [[Mozilla Thunderbird|Thunderbird]] email plugin, which must be installed separately from the Thunderbird client.
